name: market for mischmetal | mischmetal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4578/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for 'mischmetal', in the the Global geography. This is a generic market; the suppliers of this market make available this generic product by redirecting a part of the production of several more specific products.;In this market, expert judgement was used to develop product specific transport distance estimations.;'mischmetal'  is an inorganic substance containing different rare earth metals. It is solid under normal conditions of temperature and pressure. The product is modelled as a mixture of metals, containing 53% Cerium, 21% Lanthanum, 17% Neodymium, 6% Praseodymium, 0.2% Samarium, the rest consisting of Europium, Gadolinium and others.  There is no publicly available information about the consumption of this substance on a consumer level. On industrial sites, the substance is used for the manufacture of products in the following sectors: metal hydride batteries and alloying constituent in HSLA steels.

This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'mischmetal',  within the geography of Global.

This activity ends with the supply of 'mischmetal',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

exchanges.description:
The total marine transport volume differentiated into major commodity groups based on data from FearnResearch (2001): Fearnley's Annual Review 2000. Oslo: Fearnley/AS, p. 1-78. The category “Other cargo” accounts for 38% of total maritime transport volume and has been distributed on commodity groups based on the proportions of transport by rail and inland waterways.
The total marine transport volume differentiated into major commodity groups based on data from FearnResearch (2001): Fearnley's Annual Review 2000. Oslo: Fearnley/AS, p. 1-78. The category “Other cargo” accounts for 38% of total maritime transport volume and has been distributed on commodity groups based on the proportions in the marine import and export of the US in 2001-2010.
